g.text: appears to validate this conclusion with an effect size of 0.61 resulting from a
synthesis of they key outcome from four studies
Marzanoâ€™s (1998) theory-driven meta-analysis identified the overall effect size for
instructional techniques that focused on the metacognitive system as 0.72 (p 88).
We identified five studies which explicitly identified metacognitive strategies as the
focus for the intervention. These studies had an overall effect size of 0.96, based
on one key outcome identified per study. This again appears to validate one of the
conclusions of our narrative synthesis regarding the value of metacognitive
Effect sizes for different curriculum areas
We also investigated the impact on the three main curriculum areas tested in the
studies included in the review. There appears to be greater impact on pupilsâ€™
It should also be noted that the effect sizes used to calculate this are based on immediate post-tests
and there is evidence from CASE that such effects may increase over time (Adey and Shayer, 1993).
Random effects model; one key outcome selected according to study aims.
Reading (and where available reading comprehension) was selected as the key outcome as not all
of the studies were in English speaking schools
A meta-analysis of the impact of the implementation of thinking skills approaches on pupils
